message: What do you think about swear words used in a professional environment?

data.message:
It depends.
In small teams working on their own etc, cool. I as a consultant working on a client site have to be very careful not to use them, even if the people on the client use it. In a country like Egypt also using swear words may be non-female developer friendly.
It's just politics. You have to be aware what best fits the environment you want to fit in.
Thanks for the reply. However I meant swearing from a client/owner to developer/colleague.
A client and a colleague are completely different :)
For a client, you'll have to suck it up if you don't have the option to change the client. For a colleague, you should be able to talk to them or escalate the concern if it is an issue to you.

It's very hard to talk about professional / official interactions when talking about small creative teams, let alone in Egypt, where professionalism isn't always the name of the game. I suggest you ignore it.
Or you could introduce subtle bugs in your work. Passive aggressiveness FTW :D

I am a strong supporter of swear words :D

I think I might have some commits with swear words in our repositories as well :D
Mosab Ahmad doing that all the time :D

Hmmm, Mohamed Meligy's comments gave me the impression that you are complaining?! Dude, swear words are fun! :D

But yeah, I try to watch female colleagues before I swear :)
Islam,  just watch the linux kernel mailing list, or simply any interview for Linus Torvald :D
Culture and perspective, Mosab Ahmad. Being "corporate friendly" is definitely not fun, but it is a thing (and is not the only work style that works of course).
I totally agree, this is once of the many reasons I avoid corporate, freedom :D
it depends, ya3ny if you have female members within your team htb2a s3ba shwya :D

I don't know why I remember this now, but one time a leader in my company was playing mind games with the team. He asked us: You know what counts for filing sexual harassment complaints? It's only the perception of the receiver.

The intention of the person accused, or even their actual actions don't count in considering an assault case and filing it, only the perception. The actions and intention only matter later, in the investigations after the case is filed..
I have a dream! I dream of companies where both males and females are cursing and swearing! Everyone's live will be a lot easier, and more fun! :D
Mosab Ahmad it's hard to reach that dream in Egypt :D

This is not very rare in western countries. It's just you need to study the environment you are in, because what might be cool in one environment can get you in various degrees of troubles in other environments.

Alaa Attya Mohamed, yeah I know! :(

Mohamed Meligy, of course, one has to be smart not غشيم! :D
working in the software industry is just very stressing, swearing is a form of releasing stress and expressing oneself :D
P.S. I realise I'm stating the obvious to many people here but just trying to make complete statements.

Thanks to all shared their thoughts.

Another question, shouldn't one take care of his language and tone when using swear woeds because it might sound like offending someone?

I have a different dream, I dream of a world when we don't always try to find new ways to express exaguration and the current expressive words lose their power over time (remember the expression "rewesh ta7n" from the 90s? :D), I get bored of this, so now I start describing things as "very funny" instead of "I can't stop laughing", I'm trying to reverse the trend alone :D

I think it's unacceptable if a client uses strong language against you. I would immediately give a warning that I will not work under such conditions. If this warning is not acknowledged, I would liquidate the job. Within a team working on a job, I don't give a ****.
